name: NewYorker
text: When the coronavirus took hold in New York City, there was "just a feeling of desolation," a local bus operator said, "almost apocalyptic in nature." He reflects on the pandemic's early days in a new episode of #NewYorkerRadio. Listen here. https://t.co/d63DwM49yT

name: NewYorker
text:
Martin Amis's new novel feels like something of a sequel to his memoir—but a lot has happened in the 20 years since the memoir was published.
https://t.co/RkIBuHdQwx

name: NewYorker
text: The activist and sociologist George Lakey has trained activists in countries including South Africa, Thailand, and Sri Lanka in their struggles against repressive regimes. Now he is turning his attention to the U.S. https://t.co/fylHEWQPOy

name: NewYorker
text: “The people had done it so many times that they only half listened to the directions; most of them were quiet, wetting their lips, not looking around.” #NewYorkerArchive https://t.co/XuUihcleEM

name: NewYorker
text: Send invitations to your reveal four to six weeks in advance. If you buy them at a stationery store in the mall, immediately cancel the party: it’s already been revealed that you’re old. https://t.co/zrQB7lZ2c8
